info.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued September 9 at 6:36PM MDT until September 9 at 7:45PM MDT by NWS Pocatello ID
info.description:
At 636 PM MDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain over the Wapiti Burn Scar. Rain gauges indicate that between 0.5 and 1 inch of rain has fallen. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.
Excessive rainfall over the burn scar will result in debris flow moving through the Wapiti burn scar. The debris flow can consist of rock, mud, vegetation and other loose materials.
HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms in and around the Wapati Burn Scar.
SOURCE...Radar.
IMPACT...Flooding of areas in and around the Wapati Burn Scar.
Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Cape Horn Area and Banner Summit.
info.instruction:
This is a life threatening situation. Heavy rainfall will cause extensive and severe flash flooding of creeks...streams...and ditches in the Wapiti Burn Scar. Severe debris flows can also be anticipated across roads. Roads and driveways may be washed away in places. If you encounter flood waters...climb to safety.
Move away from recently burned areas. Life-threatening flooding of creeks, roads and normally dry arroyos is likely. The heavy rains will likely trigger rockslides, mudslides and debris flows in steep terrain, especially in and around these areas.
Flooding is occurring or is imminent. It is important to know where you are relative to streams, rivers, or creeks which can become killers in heavy rains. Campers and hikers should avoid streams or creeks.

parameter.value: FLASH FLOOD WARNING FOR THE WAPATI BURN SCAR REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 745 PM MDT THIS EVENING FOR WEST CENTRAL CUSTER COUNTY
